content.description: To prevent the loss of genes as chromosome ends wear down during <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication, the tips of eukaryotic chromosomes have specialized <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> “caps” called telomeres. Telomeres consist of hundreds or thousands of repeats of the same short <math alttext="D N A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> sequence, which varies between organisms. The telomeric repeat sequences for selected organisms are given in Table 1.

Telomeric Repeat Sequences for Selected Organisms Organism Telomeric Repeat Sequence (<math alttext="5 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>) Human <math alttext="T T A G G G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TTAGGG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Mouse <math alttext="T T A G G G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TTAGGG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Paramecium <math alttext="T T G G G T" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TTGGGT</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Green alga <math alttext="T T T T A G G G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>TTTTAGGG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Onion <math alttext="C T C G G T T A T G G G" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>CTCGGTTATGGG</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> Which of the following best predicts why humans and mice have identical telomeric repeat sequences?

choices.label: Humans and mice have the same number of genes.
Humans and mice have the same number of chromosomes.

Humans and mice share a recent common ancestor that had the <math alttext="5 prime, T T A G G G, 3 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mrow><mtext>TTAG</mtext><mtext>G</mtext><mtext>G</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mo lspace="0em" rspace="0em">–</mo><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> repeat sequence in its telomeres.

Mice utilized the <math alttext="5 prime, T T A G G G, 3 prime" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup><mtext>-</mtext><mrow><mtext>TTAGGG</mtext></mrow><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>-</mtext><mn>3</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> telomeric repeat sequence first, but the sequence independently evolved in humans as well.
